Reviews.Title: Hauppauge 1191 WinTV-HVR-950Q TV Tuner
Reviews.Author: D. Schnauthiel "Fishingtime"
Reviews.Content: The antenna and remote control are junk right out of the box. The end fell off the antenna and the remote control worked some of the time and then quit all together. That is the reason for the 4 star rating. On the up side the tuner stick and software work great. The unit also works great with Windows Vista Media Center. I have eliminated the TV set in my motor home and watch TV exclusively  on my laptop. I can record programs or schedule programs to be recorded, then put my laptop to sleep.  The computer will wake up and record the program. The best part is I can shrink the screen down to any size I want then set it for always on top and stick it up in the corner of the screen. I can surf the net or write a review while watching TV. As I am writing this review I have eight windows open and all is working fine. My laptop is a lower end Compaq ($500.00 range) with Windows Vista and 2 gig's of ram. If you open the box and throw the antenna and remote away you then have a 5 Star product. Changing channels is a snap, just click on the TV screen then use your number keys to select a channel.

Reviews.Title: hauppauge customer service is non existent
Reviews.Author: R. Ellis "dog lover"
Reviews.Content: After I received this tuner and it failed to install with the supplied software I contacted Hauppauge Customer Support.  They advised me the supplied software was out of date and directed me to there site.  After downloading the software, and getting the tuner partially working the remote did not function.  I contacted them, and they diagnosed it and said they would be happy to replace it.  A month and half later, they still had not replaced it, and the tuner had problems changing channels slowly, freezing, and just going blank.  After repeated calls to Hauppauge, they assured me they would send a new remote. Finally I called support again and asked if it was possible to just exchange this unit for something that would work.  They said they would be happy to for $128.00.  The tech did state that they had troubles with this unit.I am very disappointed with this product and my experience.  If you purchase one of there tuners, be advised there customer support is very non-supportive.

Reviews.Title: Good hardware, bad software
Reviews.Author: Donald E. Fulton
Reviews.Content: Hardware  When my cable provider (Comcast) announced a conversion of extended basic channels (24 to 71) to digital, I bought the Hauppauge HVR-950Q to replace my Hauppauge HVR-950, an analog only USB tuner. Picture quality with my old Hauppauge HVR-950 was fair to good on upper channels, but so noisy on lower channels that channels 2 to 7 were unwatchable. The first thing I noticed when I popped in the new HVR-950Q was a dramatic improvement in picture quality on the lower analog channels and some improvement too in upper channels. Obviously the HVR-950Q has much better noise filtering than the old HVR-950.  The quality improvement in analog channels alone is reason enough to upgrade.Temperature  A little worrying about the HVR-950Q is that the silicon inside must run pretty hot. The best way to judge this is to feel the metal ring of the cable. This tuner is powered from the computer USB port. Judging from its heat output this tuner must take most of the 2.5 watts (500 ma x 5V) that a USB port can deliver, so this tuner definitely needs its own port.Clear QAM  I knew prior to the conversion that my cable contained a large number of 'upper channels' because my large screen TV found them and displayed them with odd channel numbers like 74-3, 76-7. I initially paid little attention to them because it seemed they were mostly duplicates of lower channels, but when Comcast announced the analog to digital conversion,  I mapped them and began to suspect they were clear QAM (digital) channels. That is what they are, and they are likely to remain clear going forward because the small cable boxes (DTA's) Comcast distributes to analog customers are reportedly unable to decode encrypted channels.Software  I agree with other reviewers that the WinTV software from Hauppauge leaves a lot to be desired. Hauppauge actually has two software packages that are totally different, probably designed by separate software teams. I prefer Ver 6 which is an upgrade of the earlier Hauppauge software and features a convenient snapshot feature. However it really only works for analog channels (most the QAM channels don't display properly). It also uses about 90% of CPU capacity making other programs slow. In Ver 7 the snapshot feature (spacebar) works, but it is undocumented and saves files only in bmp format making them huge. I emailed Hauppauge customer support asking if there was a way to change the file format and never got a reply.  For receiving QAM digital and HD channels from this tuner I find the 3rd party software package BeyondTV works well. It gives an excellent picture, has a built-in program guide, and uses about 60% of the CPU capacity. It can takes a while to set up as the QAM channels need to be mapped into the standard channel numbers. You need the latest version of BeyondTV to get QAM channels, but upgrades from any version 4 are free.Comcast lack of support for computer TV tuners  During the digital transition period I found Comcast provided no support at all to those with computer TV tuners. Comcast never tells you (in literature or online) that there are 60-80 'hidden' clear QAM clear channels, including HD channels, on your cable that can be picked up with non-Comcast equipment. I talked to three Comcast service technicians and not one would confirm the existence of dozens of clear QAM channels on the cable.Comcast will not tell you about clear QAM channels  The HVR-950Q and most newer TVs if provided with a direct cable connection can provide access to the HD channels that are there. In contrast the equipment Comcast provides (for free) to support its analog customers in the transition to digital is low end, non-HD equipment, which if hooked up as Comcast recommends, blocks access to HD. My guess is that this is by design. Wikipedia in 'QAM tuner' notes, "The law does not require the cable provider to advertise the availability (of clear QAM channels), and the cable customer service representatives are known to unequivocally (and incorrectly) insist to customers that (an HD) converter box is mandatory to view any HD channels."-----------------(update) A day or two after the extended basic analog channels were taken down I found 40 or so 'upper channels' (channel numbers like 76-9, 77-4) had gone missing. Whoops, I thought I was going to eat my words about clear QAM channels remaining on Comcast, but false alarm, they all still there just at new frequencies. A week or so after the extended basic analog channels were taken down, auto scan on both this tuner and my large screen TV is finding 87 clear QAM channels (about 70 of the 87 are new channels).  I pay Comcast well over 1,000 dollars a year in cable fees, and their idea of customer service is hide the fact that there are 87 unencrypted digital channels on my cable, many of which are HD, that I can legally access with non-Comcast equipment and without signing up for Comcast digital service!

Reviews.Title: Great tuner/ recorder
Reviews.Author: Hugh Long
Reviews.Content: This is a great tuner/ video recorder. It is fully compatible with Vista and Windows Media Center. The remote control is convenience and works great with Windows Media Center. It virtually transforms your desktop/laptop into a HDTV plus a digital recorder system. Powerful hardware configuration (CPU, memory and hard disk) is strongly recommended. Recording 1 hour of HD contents (720p/1080i) in Windows Media Center requires 6 GB of hard disk space. The software package is good but I prefer Windows Media Center.

Reviews.Title: Didn't work on Win7 64-bit, XP Pro, or Vista
Reviews.Author: J. Pritchard
Reviews.Content: My review was mysteriously never posted the first time, hmm... trying again.I've seen reviews on other sites that say if it didn't work the person just didn't know what they were doing.  I'm a system administrator, not just a typical user, so trust me when I say I tried everything I could think of to get this to work on 3 different machines.  The first machine I tried was Win7 64-bit, 1 gig ATI graphics card (with latest drivers), and 6 gigs of ram.  I tried installing using the CD and the updated software on the website - which at the time was 1.2b, 1.2c came out after I had initiated the return.  I also tried just plugging it in and hoping Windows Media Center would detect it like I saw in other reviews - no luck.  Using the vendors software, it froze when searching for channels.  I even left it on over night (8+ hrs) thinking I didn't give it enough time, but it didn't matter.  Each time I tried a different way of installing it I used the cleaning utility on the CD to start from scratch.The second computer I tried was Windows XP Pro, 512mb nvidia graphics card (latest drivers), 2 gigs of ram.  I had the same exact problem, it froze when searching for channels.  The third computer I tried it on was my Vista laptop, same problem and Windows Media Center could not detect the tuner just like Windows 7.On all three computers I used the cleanup utility between installations to make sure I wasn't simply installing on top of itself.  The lights on the tuner were on indicating that the computer detected it (also showed up in device manager) and that it had a decent signal.  I forgot to mention that I tried using the Windows Media Center Installation file that Hauppauge provides on their website, obviously that didn't work either.As a last resort I reformatted my Windows 7 machine thinking (and hoping) that maybe something I had on there was conflicting with the tuner in some way.  I did not install a single thing before trying it on the clean install, but I had the same problem.Also, be warned that Hauppauge customer service is ridiculously horrible.  I tried contacting them before returning the tuner.  It took them 5 business days to reply to my first email and all the response said was "Are you connecting anything between the unit and the pc (included extension usb hub etc)?"  I responded the same day and it took another 4 business days for this response from them "Can you give me more information on the pc you are using? Do you have another pc you can try the unit on?"  Granted, I should have given them the specs to my computer in the first email.  But coming from a customer service/tech support background, the response time alone is terrible and the one sentence responses are mind blowing.  They should have combined those emails into the first response and gotten it to me within the 48 hr response time that I swear I saw on their website.  If I responded like that at my tech support job of 4 yrs I would've been in a lot of trouble.Needless to say, do your homework by reading both positive and negative reviews.  Also check out other sites to read their reviews.  I did and was hoping I'd be on the positive side, sadly I was not.

Reviews.Title: Awesome usb tuner
Reviews.Author: A. Dimitrov
Reviews.Content: Before I bought this item I read some reviews that it is changing channels very slow, crashes a lot after watching the hd channels, some ppl couldn't even get hd channels somehow.The product turned out pretty awesome! I did notice some slowness when i first connected it to my pc (vista-32, q6600, 8800gt, 4gb ram) through a pci usb hub. I was wondering why since i definitely have the horse power for the device to be running pretty fast. I hooked it up to one of the standard usb ports and it got a lot faster. Actually now it is perfect. I am able to watch atsc channels no problems whatsoever.I also tried it on my aspire one and it worked perfectly there as well!This is a great product! Thanks Amazon!

Reviews.Title: Inexpensive DVR
Reviews.Author: L. Hauenstein
Reviews.Content: I really like the product. I wanted a product that would allow me to watch the television signal coming out of the coaxial cable coming from the wall (cable company provided).  I first tried the product with the software it came with on an older laptop (4 year old HP). The software took forever to scan the signal for channels. It eventually came back with good picture quality but some static in the audio on many channels. I tried using the fine adjustment feature that the software offers with no success. Out of curiosity I tried the hardware on my daughters newer HP laptop (just over a year old, 2 ghz, 2 gb RAM). Her laptop uses Windows Media Center which works great with the hardware. After the drivers were installed Media Center found the device, quickly found all the channels (with no audio static) and even downloaded the latest channel guide for my area. Using this product and windows media center I'm now able to watch, pause, and record live tv (similar to Tivo) as well as set up recording a show or series very easily. I would recommend this product be used with newer PC's and while the manufacturer suggests teh software provided offers the same capability as media center, I'd reccomend media center if available. I wasn't able to pick up any over the air channels with the antenna provided and the remote control doesn't appear to work very well either.

Reviews.Title: Disappointed about the WinTV
Reviews.Author: C. Chen "ccchen1102"
Reviews.Content: Hauppauge 1200 WinTV HVR-850 HDTV Tuner StickHauppauge 1191 WinTV-HVR-950Q TV Tuner Stick/Personal Video Recorder with Clear QAM and Remote Control (Black)I checked the previous reviews here and  tried both 950Q and 850 (purchased locally), I ended up return both units. The HW seems to be OK, the issue is with the software, it freezes and crashes way too often. I think if you have a WinXP system without MCE, you don't want to consider this brand. The software is written poorly: - On Analog or Non-HD digital channel, it takes 40-50% of CPU power on my Vaio S560, 1.8Ghz Pentium M + 1.5G memory. On HD digital channel, it takes 70-80% CPU power. Switching from Analog to HD would crash the WinTV version 6, Switching from Analog to Non-HD digital then to HD is the way to workaround it, but if you kill the app when it was at HD, the app crashes every time it launches, to workaround it, you'd have to unplug the cable (so there is no signal) before launch, annoying!! Isn't it?Pctv HD Stick USB Hd Atsc Ntsc Clearqam TunerI've bought Pinnacle PCTV HD Stick since and this is the one I will keep, the PCTV user interface is very well done, the main window can be resized to really small, the channel switching is faster, it also takes up less CPU power on Analog and Non-HD digital at around 20% (70%-80% for HD). The software does lock up a couple times, however, this rarely occurs.

Reviews.Title: What a pile of junk
Reviews.Author: Toy
Reviews.Content: Where to begin. First off, the remote (if you can even call it that) did not work out of the box. It uses a watch battery and I do not have another to test with. So forget that and lets move on. The WinTV software that ships with the unit works mediocre until you try to do anything at all (like change the channel or schedule a recording)then it freezes and loses signal. That was WinTV 6. So I went to Hauppauges site and saw there is a WinTV 7 available. I tried it, and what a sorry excuse for software. I think it was written by a group of eighth graders trying a computer lab project. It froze with exception occured errors, both on an XP machine AND a Vista machine. The few times it did work, I had to watch TV in a small window. Clicking on the full screen button resulted in choppy blocky artifacts that would not play. Hauppauge has a support forum, and if you go there you will see many asking for help but the employees are not even active on it's own forum. Regular users try to help! If this tuner device was $10 I might have kept it just to try and play with at a later date. At $70? No freaking way. Save yourself some money and headaches and skip this pile of junk all together.

Reviews.Title: Nothing but trouble
Reviews.Author: P. J. Botha
Reviews.Content: The unit looks to be well made, but I experienced only trouble getting it to work.At first the device was not recognized.  Hauppauge tech support had no solution, instead suggesting that the unit may be defective.  After spending an entire day, I discovered that the unit is a Composite USB device, and requires the usb.inf file in WinXP.  Mine was missing.  After getting a copy from another machine, I was able to install the drivers successfully.Next the WinTV install program causes a data execution error.  Browsing the disk and installing the software manually worked OK.After scanning for channels, I was able to watch TV for a few minutes, and then it froze.  The software is still responsive, but no video or audio.  You have to shut down the software, unplug and re-insert the receiver.  At this point it only works for about 10 seconds before freezing.After more experimentation the next day, it appears that as soon as the unit warms up (just a few minutes), it freezes.I am returning this unit.  I got a Pinnacle PCTV HD Pro stick from Best Buy that is working great.

Reviews.Title: It works, but only thanks to Windows 7 MC
Reviews.Author: Pger
Reviews.Content: I bought this unit just so I could watch TV while working at home on my computer (talk about ADD). At first I thought the unit was dead cause it was recognized once, then dead for a couple of days. I reinstalled their software (from CD and online update) numerous times to no avail. Tried it on my other laptop without any luck. Was ready to throw it out the window but by chance I was also ready to upgrade from XP to Win 7 around the same time. I installed Win 7 and Media Center and bingo! It was recognized just fine (after also installing the Win 7 MC Hauppage patch). So in the end the thing is working ok and I can use it efectevely. However, I am amazed about the crappy software and installation support that comes with this product. It is also very hard to find a TV tuner with great ratings accross the board, it always seems so hit and miss, not sure why the can't get their act straight.

Reviews.Title: A good buy but...
Reviews.Author: Eagle Spirit
Reviews.Content: This is a solid product and works well for providing the signal needed, however, the software still has glitches. I called tech support and downloaded the latest version and the problems still persist. The software kept freezing even after repeatedly rebooting my computer and uninstalling and installing it. I recommend, if you have Windows 7 with Windows Media Center on your pc to use it. Windows Media Center provides a far superior software platform along with providing additional free tv programs to watch, even a few free programs from Showtime. This product receives 4 stars because: it is a solid and excellent functioning hardware product but the software lacks smooth performance. (If this helps you, please click on yes button).

Reviews.Title: Clear QAM on Mac, Not on Vista's Media Center
Reviews.Author: Re2st
Reviews.Content: The reason I picked this is because it works BOTH on Mac and PC. On Mac, Elgato's EyeTV is just the best piece of software. It just works. Install the software, pick HVR-950Q, connect your cable's coax, and scan the channels. It picks up all the Clear QAM as well as analog ATSC from your cable company.The include antenna is, indeed very cute. It picks up all those big local channels that matter (ABC, NBC, Fox, CBS that kinda thing). Using it on a laptop (in my case, MacBook Pro) is absolutely delightful. In fact, I'm getting another antenna for my desktop, so I can interchange my source between cable and off-air antenna (sometimes, off-air antenna has better quality than cable, not to mention some broadcasts that are only available off-air).On a PC, it works with Vista Media Center if you're planning to use analog cable and digital off-air antenna. Vista Media Center won't recognize the clear-QAM. If you've ever heard of TV Pack 2008 for Vista Media Center, I tried that too, but not working with HVR-950Q (not yet, hopefully, we still need proper drivers from Hauppauge). I have a HVR-1800, and it works on Vista Media Center with TV Pack perfectly, picking up all the clear QAM. So, for Vista, your option is the crappy WinTV (speaking of which, has never picked up and clear QAM channel AND show them properly on my HVR-1800), or one of those other 3rd party options (SageTV, BeyondTV and so on, but I tried both, none of which could pick any clear QAM. Not sure what the problem is, maybe just me). You might also want to check GB-PVR, an open source software. That was what I have been using for my HVR-1800 up until I installed TV Pack 2008. But then again, it's still buggy as h*ll, not as elegant as Vista Media Center, and not really consumer-friendly.Anyway, if you plan on using this on a Mac with EyeTV, it's PEERFECT. But if you want to use it on a PC with Media Center, it only supports off-air antenna for digital signal (unless you want to use WinTV or other 3rd party software)

Reviews.Title: Great tuner and works with Linux too
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: I guess I have had this for about a year. Haven't used it much until the recent death of two tvs. I have never tried it with windoze but in both Ubuntu and Debian linux it works great as long as you have kernel version 2.6.30 or higher. It is far more sensitive than either the converter boxes or digital ready tvs I have used. With those, I was always having to get up and adjust the antenna especially after changing channels and if there was even a slight breeze I would loose my signal altogether but with the hvr950 I not only get all my channels with the antenna in one place but I'm pulling in more stations. I have found out you need a fast processor for hd. I tried it with an Intel Atom, (about 1.6 ghz I think) and while it would play most sd stations fine it was too slow for hd. On my amd athlon 64 x2 it never misses. I think the company recommends 2.3 ghz or higher.

Reviews.Title: Haupauge WinTV how did I live without tv on my computer!
Reviews.Author: Lisa B. Mclain "At home worker"
Reviews.Content: Received the item in less than 48 hours with Amazon Prime shipping, plugged it in and started up Windows Media Center and walked through the wizard and off it went. I know get 99 channels.I am running Windows Vista Home Ultimate- I plugged our coax cable into the tuner plugged tuner into the fron USB 2.0 port.That was really all there was to it except for the wizard. I did not even mess with Wintv. I suspect there are other channels or use of the antenna that others have tried but I was thrilled with just being able to watch television on my new 22 " monitor. I had been watching a tiny old television that was perched to one corner of my office. I work from home and it's great to be able to catch up on news etc in the corner of my screen. One of those luxuries that you absolutely do not need.. but wonder how you got along without!

Reviews.Title: Not Stable
Reviews.Author: D. Hill "Jazzin"
Reviews.Content: Performance is erratic. Slow response when changing channels and software locks up frequently on channel change. Display goes black when window frame touches a screen boundary for no reason.

Reviews.Title: Hauppage 950Q setup and performance
Reviews.Author: Oly Guy "Oly"
Reviews.Content: Why Purchased  . . . . My desktop computer's monitor is a 2+ year old wall-mounted 19" (16:10) Samsung 940MW with an NTSC TV tuner, speakers, and PIP built-in.  I like the monitor and its PIP function (not available in new monitors), but after the digital transition this summer its internal tuner received little.  Connecting it to a DVD recorder with an ATSC/QAM tuner fixed that, but I wanted more flexibility, DVR functionality, and the ability to move the tuner occasionally to a laptop.  The Hauppage 950Q seemed a good & relatively inexpensive solution.My Equipment . . . . Desktop = 64-bit quad 4 CPU, 4 MB RAM, 600 GB HD.  Laptop = 32-bit dual core CPU, 3 MB RAM, 160 GB HD w/15.4" screen.  OS = Vista Home Premium.  Cable Service = Comcast.Initial Setup . . . . With a cable splitter and a longer USB extension cord, I positioned the 950Q with enough space to let the tuner's heat dissipate, so the remote could easily see it, and so it's easily removable when I want to use it with my laptop.  Drivers and WinTV7 software installed seamlessly, and the "Digital QAM" channel-scan took about 15 minutes.  Similar process for the laptop, but just scanned for OTA ATSC channels using the included antenna.Configuration AFTER Setup . . . . The cable scan found around 180 unencrypted channels, seven of which were HD.  Each of the HD channels also had a differently numbered separate SD channel.  Comcast's 40-some music channels were included twice.  Channel names on everything were listed as "Unknown".  To make this more manageable, I used WinTV7's "Configuration" utility to delete redundant and not-my-taste music channels, to add channel names (NBC, CBS, CNN, ESPN, etc.), and to assign simple consecutive ID numbers for logical channel ordering and for the remote (1, 2, 3, 4 . . . 85, 86, etc).  Initial set-up and scan took only an hour or so.  Configuration was much more painful - took most of a rainy Sunday afternoon/evening.Experience and Satisfaction . . . . My monitor has 1400x900 dpi resolution and uses a DVI port for computer connection.  With this, HD channels are spectacular and SD channels are good.  Channel changes take a couple of seconds (acceptable), the DVR function is nice (30 minute buffer), and the recording scheduler works well (I save recordings as .mpg files).  The 950Q's remote is a convenience, and also operates basic functions in Windows Media Center.  OTA performance on my laptop with the included antenna ranges from very good to nothing, varying with its location.  I've had no problems with WinTV7 crashing.Bottom Line . . . . I'll rate it a 5 for picture quality and features AFTER setup, and a 3 for the pain of configuration during setup.  Overall a well-satisfied 4.  I can now window and watch CNN and a football game in the background while updating spreadsheets or correspondence without the need for space-eating separate monitors. Nice.  Total cost was $80, including splitter and USB extension cord.Concerns . . . . As others have mentioned, the 950Q does get very hot when operating - a factor that gives me some worry about its longevity.  But since it comes with a 2 year manufacturer's warranty, that worry may be unfounded.  Of less importance, the remote is sometimes temperamental, and its very small size makes it easily losable.

Reviews.Title: Have Media Center (Windows), MythTV(Linux)? Then go ahead.
Reviews.Author: Centodeon
Reviews.Content: Software:The software bundled with the product is appallingly lousy. I initially bought it because its drivers were available in linux. It works with Media Center (Windows -- please beware, only specific editions have this), and MythTV (linux -- I tested it on Fedora).Hardware:With antenna, it gets few channels, and even with good positioning, frozen frames, lost channels and frequent failures of detection by Windows is not uncommon.

Reviews.Title: Don't waste your time on this item unless you have...
Reviews.Author: Samuel A. Travolta
Reviews.Content: This item does not work with an HP dv5-1235dx. I bought this tv tuner based off of positive reviews. I even added a motorola power amp for 50 dollars. If you have a lot patience to wait 10 minutes before the tuner loads and you are interested in investing alot of money on a external digital attenna. Then please be my guest. I did the research and it is a good company, just don't expect it to work without a lot of super memory or like a regular tv. Picture is outstanding when it works, but when you got to full screen tv from 5 inches it crashes. I called haupage tech support but they never got back to me so i returned it. And I was charged 11 dollars by amazon for returning it because it was not there fault and it was shipped for free so that was fair. Stay away from this product unless you have a lot of time or money to burn.

Reviews.Title: Worked beautifully right out of the box
Reviews.Author: J. Valiulis
Reviews.Content: I was hesitant to buy this thing because of all the negative reviews from people who could not get it to work. I want to be able to watch and record Over-the-air (OTA) TV using an antenna. I have a not-so-great HP Elitebook laptop running Windows 7 Professional. I followed the directions in the box to get the device recognized by the computer, I installed the latest drivers from the Happauge website (just Google "Hauppauge 950Q manual" to find the page with lots of additional resources, instructions and drivers), went through a first-time configuration of Windows Media Center, and I was watching, pausing and recording TV shows. It's that easy.

Reviews.Title: Great idea, questionable execution! Not recommended.
Reviews.Author: Robert M. Woolf "The Olde Greywoolf"
Reviews.Content: First off, I should say that my system has more than enough horsepower to run this device without any problem (HP DV9500 CTO, 4 GB RAM, Intel T7500 2.2 GHtz Duo-2 CPU, 1.5 TB disk space, Vista Ultimate 64X, etc.).  Unfortunately, the reality is otherwise.The WinTV 7 software that comes with it is very poor with lots of hang ups, crashes and faults.  So I use the Windows Media Center which works quite well, as long as the 950 does.  About 20 - 30 % of the time the tuner reports "loss of signal" or "data rate low" or "digital audio service (w/ sound but no picture).  When it does that it locks up the entire system.  WMC will NOT close, stops responding to all inputs, and the only way out of it is a hard reboot of the computer.When it works, with WMC, it works pretty well - good picture, synced sound, changes channels OK (but slow as hell), etc.  But that is only SOME of the time.  About one quarter of my recorded shows come out as 2 or more pieces with gaps between.  Hate that.I have tried dealing with their tech support - a challenge in and of itself.  I even sent the unit back to them for repair, etc.  I got it back, but no notice of what, if any, action they took.  Now the unit works worse than before.  Standard TV's and tuners in the same room, fed off the same cable line have no such issues.One more thing, even with the horsepower I have and 64x, running ANY other application while using the 950Q is just about a 100% guarantee of a system crash.  It's a total resource hog.  Don't plan on doing ANYTHING with your system when you are viewing OR recording TV.  Won't work.  Even an incoming email or IM will crash it.As of now I am looking to buy a different brand USB tuner.  This one has left me unimpressed, frustrated and greatly disappointed.

Reviews.Title: Sorry to say, but this is not worth your frustration !
Reviews.Author: Benjamin A. Burn "-Benjamin"
Reviews.Content: I bought this to use on a Brand new windows 7 machine. Software is buggy. Crashes when changing any channels.I have to unplug it to make anything work right on my computer's built in USB "no hub" so as not to crash the os components such as backup, format etc. (Lost a whole backup hard drive trying to use it)Remote control only works if you literally put the remote up to the receiver and press the buttons repetitively. Checked RC battery 3.2 VSpent three whole days trying to get this thing to work. Not at all worth your time.I wish I could return it however I had it shipped out of the country so too much postage to return it.Best of luck,-Benjamin

Reviews.Title: Maybe it's just my problem.
Reviews.Author: C. Mitchell
Reviews.Content: Hi.  I am certainly no tech whiz, but I absolutely could not get this product to recognize my cable feed from the wall, which was my sole reason for purchase.  Yes, it did pick up a few channels over the air so I am not going to complain about that.  I was trying to run it on my Acer Aspire One with 2GB ram, 1.7mhz processor, and 250gb hardrive.  The bundled software would not pick up the cable nor would Windows Media Center running on Windows 7 Home premium.  I e-mailed support at Hauppauge but did not hear back from them only after a couple of days.  Granted, I only fooled with the product for two days and then I decided to cut my losses and just return it to Amazon.

Reviews.Title: huge dissapointment and waste of money
Reviews.Author: Matthew L. Jones
Reviews.Content: I bought this product after reading the reviews and I decided to ignore the bad ones.  I was wrong.  The wintv keeps freezing and locking up so you have to restart your computer when it is on digital channels.  So I bought the Terk indoor hd digital antanna to see if it was the signal and it  still had the same problem.  I only get two of the local channels and it lags alot.  this product was not worth the money at all.  Only buy this product if you want to waste money.  I will never buy hauppauge again!

Reviews.Title: Great little device
Reviews.Author: Michael N
Reviews.Content: I like this little guy.  First, the antenna worked great in my area.  I have another $100 over-the-air HD antenna, and this one pulled in the same stations, in spite of its much smaller size.  The HD over-the-air stations in my area are full 1080p, and the TV viewer displayed great quality on my HD monitor.  After trying several different scans, I found I was able to do a Clear QAM scan of my cable as well.  Pulled in a lot of channels, but mostly the same over-the-air channels plus some junk stations.  I decided to stick with the over-the-air antenna.Hauppauge wisely ships this unit with a USB extension cable.  I initially thought that they included this cable because the device is a little wider than a typical USB connector, and might impede access to other adjacent ports on the computer.  While this is true, the better reason is that a coax cable + the adapter could put some undue torque on the USB port.  I used the extender cable primarily for this reason.  Also, when I attached my cable TV coax to the device, that part of the device became very hot after a while (probably all those encrypted premium channels I don't get...LOL).  But I decided to make sure I do put papers or anything flammable around or on top of the device.  The device only gets warm with the over-the-air antenna, but this is probably a good safety practice for any active electronic device.The software is pretty easy to use.  There is a good set of help screens that are not verbose, and do a good job explaining everything.  The recorder works well.  During the scan, I got alerts for high disk activity, but not after the scan was completed.  Not a big deal.  The screen hiccups once in a while, and the manual says this is probably due to other activity in the computer.  My task manager did not show a lot going on, so I consider this to be something to watch.  Thus only 4 out of 5 stars.Be advised that the remote control (which I consider unnecessary) comes set to work with Windows Media Center, not the WinTV7 program that comes with the product.  I haven't tried to reconfigure the remote to work with WinTV7, and maybe you can't.  I also haven't tried using Windows Media Center instead of WinTV7, but I will get to that in time.  All in all, I think the product works well.

Reviews.Title: Just works!!
Reviews.Author: M. Jaber
Reviews.Content: Bought this Tuner and very happy.  I used it on Windows Vista and worked with no problems.  I connected my cable to it.  It picked the Clear QAM signal on the cable and also the non-digital cable signals.  Without the Cable and using the included antenna, I picked up most of the local channels (amazing picture - better than cable).  The included software is very good, but I used Windows Media Center.  Media Center had no prolem working with this Tuner.This device just works. I am very pleased with it.

Reviews.Title: this is a keeper
Reviews.Author: RRRut
Reviews.Content: first off, this turned out to be great product. my initial thinking was that it would be for both my laptop and home based pc. my home pc (Gateway GT5622) did and still does have some issues when looking at higher-res HD channels via the 950Q. an enormous amount of memory is taken up (up to 250Mb) and the CPU gets challenged a bit (45-60%). all the while my HD channels remain choppy. for me in my area, Verizon FIOS offers two flavors of digital programming per broadcasting network (i.e. ABC, CBS, NBC, FOX, even PBS) and for the most part you can tell by aspect ratio what you're getting. so when the HD version gets too choppy, i just tune to the less taxing and lower resolution digital channel and it's fine though not as clear. so why the 5 stars???...on my laptop (Dell Vostro 1700, 17" monitor) which ostensibly has less horsepower than my desktop, the digital channels are like a true HDTV flatscreen television, I AM SERIOUS!!! and if i could have given this little thumbdrive-looking tuner a 6, i would have.I don't know why the desktop (Windows Vista, Intel Dual CPU E 2160, 1.5G RAM) has so much trouble and the laptop (Windows XP, 2.0GHz CPU) does not, perhaps the GeForce card in the laptop is helping...I dunno. But a 4 for the desktop and a 6 for the laptop gives you a 5!!!!

Reviews.Title: Attention Mac Users...
Reviews.Author: Kevin Nicholls "jaded, aging hipster"
Reviews.Content: Save yourself some cash, and pick this up instead of the Elgato EyeTV Hybrid (but be sure to buy an EyeTV 3 license from Elgato's site).With the EyeTV 3 software, the WinTV is immediately recognized, and works beautifully. The auto-scan worked exactly as I had hoped it would -- finding ATSC and NTSC channels, and displays channel and programming info properly on channels that broadcast it.The included AV jacks on a whip make this a nice and cheap solution for transferring video from VHS or older camcorders that don't speak USB or FireWire/1394.There are only two things I can really complain about:1) The unit itself is relatively large for a USB device. I'd probably use a USB hub or extension if you keep your computer in an enclosure, as this easily adds about 3" to the rear depth of any desktop system.2) There's nothing inherently Windows-centric about this product, other than Hauppage not including any Mac software with the bundle. Recognizing of course, that they make no claim whatsoever that it works with a Mac, let alone comes with software.

Reviews.Title: Immediately recognized by WMC WIN7 64 bit, no issues
Reviews.Author: iman "iman"
Reviews.Content: Easily installed without any special drivers having to be installed. WIN 7 WMC recognized it and allowed scanning of digital and analog channels. Media Guide works well for recording which none has been missed since having it about 6 weeks. Works great. The price was a little higher when I bought it and is really the only con to buying it. Otherwise I would recommend it to anyone with WIN 7.

Reviews.Title: great device, don't like remote
Reviews.Author: D. Gardner
Reviews.Content: I'm very happy with this.  I use it on Windows 7 with the windows media center.  I got it up and running easily and found about 25 channels.  I didn't expect so many channels with the cheesy little antenna (your results may vary, depending on your location).I had some trouble with the remote.  I had to run their program "restart IR" to make it work, or else restart windows while the device is plugged in (I like to plug the device in only when I want to watch TV).  In any case, I don't like the remote much.  I have to press the buttons hard to get them to work, then they sometimes trigger twice.  I just use my keyboard instead.In retrospect, I would have just bought the one without the remote.Without the remote, I give it five stars.P.S. The included usb extension cable (about 12") helps a lot, since the device is kind of wide.  With the extension cable, you don't have to block any of your nearby usb ports.-------------------------update: I just added an indoor amplified vhf/uhf antenna my brother gave me.  It didn't bring in any more channels, but it made a very big improvement in the quality of the channels I do get, especially the public tv stations.  I definitely recommend upgrading the antenna.

Reviews.Title: Did not work
Reviews.Author: Henry Escolano
Reviews.Content: After installing the drivers, updated drivers and WinTV 7, I tried setting up the channels. As soon as I try to scan, the app freezes up and won't shut down. I have no control in the window and can't click the cancel button. It won't close even when I try to shut it down with window's task manager and I try to shut down the application or the process. I need to reboot my computer to shut it down. I went to the forums looking for a solution and found that someone had success installing WinTV 6. Same results as before. There may be Windows 7 issues or 64 bit issues. The information on the box stated that this will work with Win 7 64 bit but I saw in the forums that other people were having issues also.

Reviews.Title: Great Product if you have Patience
Reviews.Author: Ryan
Reviews.Content: I bought this product several months ago from Amazon and overall I've been pleased with it. There are some strong points about the Tuner, and some cons as well:ProsI like how it has the ASTC and NTSC tuner one one input so multiple cables are not needed to get HD QAM channels and SD analogue channels.I was also very satisfied with how simply this worked with Windows 7 64-bit; I literally just plugged it in and Windows recognized it and it was working just fine.I honestly have not used the software that came with it, nor the remote control. I attempted to use the software for a TV Tuner long ago and had nothing but problems with it. Ever since then, I've just used Windows Media Center to watch TV and haven't had a single problem. The set-up was easy and the guide and 10-foot interface is very easy to use and looks great! I also had a USB IR receiver and Media Center remote that I had from a previous Tuner that I used instead of the small, cramped one that came with this.ConsThe biggest con that, to me at least, really damages the product on the whole is the lack of a hardware MPEG-2 encoder. At first I didn't think that this was going to be a problem, as my computer is fairly hardy and I thought it could handle it.Be warned, this tuner takes a long time to switch channels.Maybe it is just because I used a hardware tuner for so long that I got used to channel changing being almost instantaneous.Also, this is just a slight con that is pretty personal to me but the blue LED on the side of the tuner stays on even when the computer is not on and it is quite bright.ConclusionOn the whole, this is a nice little TV tuner that would be greatly suited for a laptop or other mobile device without a PCI or PCI-Express slot for a better tuner. It has great functions and works wonderfully with Windows 7 and Windows Media Center. The only hindrance is the card's slow tuning capability. If you are getting this card for a laptop, go ahead. If you're getting it for a desktop, try something like this:  Hauppauge 1183 WinTV HVR-1600 Internal PCI Dual TV Tuner/Video Recorder Media Center Kit You'll get much better results.

Reviews.Title: Adequate
Reviews.Author: Michael LaBossiere
Reviews.Content: On the plus side, the device works reasonable well. Set up is fairly easy-install the software (be sure to download the latest version from the web site and make sure that any security software is set to allow the install)and then plug in the device. It works better plugged directly into a USB port on the PC rather than into a hub.While the software for the device is okay, it is generally better to install the Windows Media center software for the device (download from the support page) and use that (assuming you have it).On the downside, the device has some stuttering problems. I have a gaming PC (9GB of RAM, i7 Processor) and the sound and image will start getting "jerky" at time. Obviously, it is not because my PC lacks power. I've tried various fixes, but have yet to find a permanent solution. Another downside is that the remote control is, to be generous, cheap. However,this was not a concern for me because I sit right in front of my PC and hence don't need the remote.Overall, it is a decent product.

Reviews.Title: Hardware OK- Software sucks
Reviews.Author: P. Lange
Reviews.Content: I use Vista. I  switch back and forth between Analog VHS and Digital TV signals. If it is left tuned to the analogue station and re-loads without that signal the software freezes. Requires a system reboot to get it to work. Found that it worked better with the original software, but Vista sneaked in a upgrade and screwed it up again.Should have paid more attention to the other reviewers that complained about the software.Oh yeah, For the life of me I could not get Vista's TV player software to recognise it.The remote is an "iffy" thing. sometimes it works, sometimes not.

Reviews.Title: Unreliable - not worth the frustration
Reviews.Author: Arch D. Robison
Reviews.Content: I bought a 950Q from Amazon in December with intent to use it as a PVR.  I started trying to use it in January.  So far I have successfully recorded 3 hours of programming, and spent many more hours of frustrated attempts to get it working.I have tried it on two systems, both with Core-2 Duo hardware: one with Windows XP Media Center (SP3) and one with Windows 7.  I.e., these are reasonably modern systems, with two different supported OSes.  ATSC TV reception in my area is mediocre, but nonetheless my DTV reports a signal strength that is 90%-100%.  I also tried the 950Q on analog signals coming straight out of my DVD player, which are presumably strong.The installer is poorly programmed.  It pops up various windows on top of each other, often before I can read or click on options in the underlying window.  It was often unclear whether the installer had really finished or hanged.  I've never done so many reinstalls and reboots for anything else to get it working as I had to do for the 950Q software.The 950Q, for both ATSC and analog reception, regularly hangs during the channel scan. Even scanning for the strong signal out of the DVD player often resulted in a hang.  There appears to be no way to enter channels manually.  After many hours of trying and retrying various setups, I got lucky and a scan didn't hang.  Then it was usable for three weeks as a recorder.  Now it is back to hanging.  The hangs even stop the host machine from shutting down properly.  I have to cycle the power.Even when it was working, playback by its "WinTV 7" application was unreliable.  Its fast forward feature sometimes does not do anything at all, and other times hangs, or won't stop.The signal strength reporting by the device is poor - there's either a green light for excellent, a yellow light for good, or nothing at all.  A variable signal strength indicator, as on my DTV unit, would be immensely helpful.  There is no signal strength indicator during the channel scan.  You need another device (I used my DTV) to check the signal strength when doing that.Customer support by email does respond within 48 hours, but not much quicker either.  So expect a "chess by mail" kind of experience if you have problems too.The picture looks good when it works.

Reviews.Title: It works and that is saying something Good !
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer "Flo"
Reviews.Content: Well I wasn't so sure this would do what it said. Some of the high tech gadgets  just don't work well Well this little gadget brings in HD Tv stations on my netbook.. but I have to say I was surprised that it pulled in any TV stations . I live approx 27 miles from the Tampa area. I was only able to pull in one station but that one was very clear and vivid. I then tried it when I visited another location approx 60 miles north. and was able to get 4 stations.. from Orlando area.1.Installation was a breeze... just plug into the USB port and add the antenna.  I even added a Terk Antenna and it was just find. I used the Media Center access and it was easy if you followed the direction EXACTLY as provided on the website. I did not use the CD that came with the product but got the most up to date  program from the website.  2. I have used this on both my laptop and net book with equal success. I feel this would work even better if I were within 10-15 miles of the major broadcasting center. When I did talk with the Company that advised 10 miles from broadcast antenna would be  best case.3. This unit works better than the 2 battery operated tV's I tried prior to this purchase and this item is cheaper.4. good for everday as well as in emergency situations using my netbook with 6 hr of battery power.So far .. pretty happy with this product and would recommend this item to others.

Reviews.Title: Not great
Reviews.Author: Q. Pham
Reviews.Content: Pixelation is a big problem,even with outdoor antenna. The problem is worsen when recording, even with Dell Studio Core2Duo processor, 64 bit, 4G RAM. The device got quite hot after 10 minutes.

Reviews.Title: should be a little smarter
Reviews.Author: W. wright
Reviews.Content: It was an easy purchase and quick ship. The device arrived and I installed the software, connected it to my laptop USB port and went through all 3 optional channel programming modes.  In the two modes I learned that without a cable company Set-top-box this device would not make much sense out of my straight digital CATV feed. In trying the analog antenna mode it only picked up 4 channels - even though I gave it an antenna connection and am located in a strong signal area. Of the channels it did 'find' it could not pick up the call letters so it knew and labeled the channels by the frequency - I'm a bit of a cable guy but even I do not like to channel surf by frequency. There seemed to be no way for the user to label the channels with names like 'NBC' or 'FOX' so I saw that as a short coming.  Lastly I noted that the device became quite HOT as it ran for about 30/45 minutes.  Thinking it might damage itself, I unplugged it and have not tried it again since. I recommend the AVerMedia TV Box 9 over a USB TV tuner - sorry

Reviews.Title: I'm using this Hauppauge HVR-950Q with Elgato EyeTV software on a Mac
Reviews.Author: BB
Reviews.Content: I have a Mac mini and I'm using an Elgato EyeTV 250 Plus. I wanted PiP (Picture in Picture) but you need a second tuner for that feature. This Hauppauge model is listed on the Elgato web sight as being compatible with their Mac software and would give me the Pip feature. It is compatible but you need to use EyeTV 3 software.If you are using a Mac and Elgato's EyeTV 2.5 software, the Hauppauge won't be recognized. You'll need to purchase the EyeTV 3 software DVD. Downloading the EyeTV 3 "upgrade" from Elgato WON'T enable the software to recognize the Hauppauge 950Q. Hauppauge eMailed me and stated I would need to  install the latest Elgato 3 software from the EyeTv 3 DVD in order for their 950Q to be recognized. Installing the EyeTV 3 software from their DVD did the trick. It remembers all of your settings etc. I now have PiP.I prefer using two TV windows instead of one with PiP because I have a 30" display and screen real estate isn't a problem.BTW I ended up purchasing  a refurbished Elgato Hybrid ($79, get on OWC's mailing list) from Other World Computing which included the EyeTV 3 DVD. $79 is only a few dollars more than the EyeTV 3 DVD alone. I ended up killing two birds with one stone. If your not in a hurry maybe you can get a deal like me and scoop up a refurbished Hybrid with the EyeTV 3 DVD. If you can't wait then I CAN recommend the Hauppauge but you MUST use EyeTV 3 software (NOT the downloadable upgrade ).If you end up having to buy the EyeTV 3 DVD to make the Hauppauge work then this Hauppauge might not be such a good deal.

Reviews.Title: It died on the second use.
Reviews.Author: M. Pekarek "creativewriter"
Reviews.Content: Purchased this new (unfortunately at a Big Box store) and used it exactly twice--and it was carefully stored in between the month I was getting a new computer.  It worked perfectly last week for an hour.  Now it's completely dead, and I'm out $99 because it has been more than a month.  All my other USB items are working perfectly on this new laptop.  I'm so disappointed after the decent reviews and am back to square one, so beware this one for reliability.

Reviews.Title: What a waste of time!
Reviews.Author: None "None"
Reviews.Content: I could not get this thing to work correctly i spend around 6 hours total it was a waste of time. You can't change the channels it takes about a minute. I try XP, Vista, Win7 nothing worked the way i imagined it would have.

Reviews.Title: A great little device
Reviews.Author: Paul Gifford
Reviews.Content: I bought this tuner for travel - the military was sending me far far away, though they were nice enough to provide cable TV to my room.  I didn't want to mail myself a TV, plus as a longtime TiVo user I don't think I know how to watch a TV show when it's actually scheduled.  Since I was bringing a laptop I figured this would be the perfect combination of TV tuner and DVR yet take up little space.Before I left I hooked up the antenna and found I was able to received HD channels right off the air.  So far so good, though it wasn't a very useful discovery to me personally since we already get HD through our FiOS connection.In the far far away land to which I was sent, one of the first things I did was hook up the cable and fire up the software.  In just a couple of minutes the software had identified the dozen or so channels available to me and I was ready to go.The hardware piece is small - just slightly larger than a USB drive.  The included USB extension cable is about 18 inches long and is a nice convenience - with it you don't have the coaxial cable pulling directly on your USB port.The included software, while usable, is not too friendly.  It's straightforward to use but requires a lot of clicking around to set up the channels and programs to record.  The software's only redeeming feature is it records shows as MPEG files (extension mpg), so they can be played back with any software, or even edited using a movie editor.I prefer to use Windows Media Center, which plays nicely with this unit.  It's easy to use with a friendly user interface.  The recordings are in a proprietary format, however.  This doesn't matter to me since I just watch the shows and delete them.Others have complained about CPU usage, speed of channel changing, and the heat the unit puts out.I haven't experienced any issues with recording or playback, but my laptop is new and has a dual core processor.  CPU usage runs between 25-40%.  Channel changing is slower than my TiVo, but not greatly so.  When I'm watching live TV or recording a show the unit does get warm but that's not unexpected considering the amount of circuitry packed into this little device.  Not long ago you'd need a much larger box or a card installed in your computer to receive video signals - now you can watch HD tv on your computer using a device the size of a cigarette lighter - how cool is that?I'm glad I got the 950Q - it does everything I need.  I've got no complaints about the hardware, but the software could be better.

Reviews.Title: Works great
Reviews.Author: Ed Sku "Edge3333"
Reviews.Content: Easy installation on my new Dell 17 inch laptop.  Works great with included antenna, external digital antenna, and Cox analog cable.  It's just perfect for my purposes.  It does run hot, however.  I wonder about long term reliability....no problems after running continuously for 3 days.

Reviews.Title: Works on Mac w/ Eye TV 3.0.3 and above
Reviews.Author: A. Cardinale
Reviews.Content: Summary: Buy it, best one out there and a bargain!I bought the 950Q because it came with a remote, qualified for Amazon Prime and was bundled with an antenna all for under $100 dollars. It did not say it was supported on the Mac, and I took a gamble...it paid off.It works great with the latest version of EyeTV(3.0.3) on the Mac(10.5.4 and 10.5.3 tested), even the remote is supported through the receiver on the device itself.Don't even bother with the WinTV software. A terrible interface and sluggish response makes it a chore to turn into even a quick news broadcast.It works OK with Vista Ultimate Media Center, but it does not have the same guide/channel source as EyeTV so I have only got the analog cable channels to work or the OTA HD broadcasts to work, but not the unencrypted HD channels on the digital cable connection.Oh yes, the included "antenna"...it might work if you are outside but barely picks up 1/3 of the channels inside. If I take the thing on my next trip I would imagine in would pick up channels in the hotel room in the center of a city...if you were facing the transmitting antennas. But who cares...it is kind of cute.

Reviews.Title: Works well, and not just on Windows.
Reviews.Author: Farscape 1 "George"
Reviews.Content: OK... let's get something straight right up front:  Most computer products plaster Windows logos all over their equipment as if it's a talisman to boost sales.  It is.  I have no problem with this. Over half of the PC users in the world use Windows.  That, I have a problem with.  It means those of us who do not tend to get left out a bit.  This is terribly sad, as competition drives companies to do better.  Lack of competition forces us to purchase unrepentant crap at ten times the value.I won't review this product on Windows.  There are over 300 reviews for that already.  Instead, I shall review it's performance for Linux «Fedora and Ubuntu, others as well, but those I can say with assurance», and tell you what you need to know to get started.Because, let there be no mistake, THIS PRODUCT WORKS ON LINUX!  It says this nowhere on the box, nor anywhere in the documentation.  No software is provided for this purpose. But that's just fine.  We don't need no stinking software!Rant over.  Now, on to the product.The antenna is *rubbish*.  This is fine.  The box was a bit ambiguous as to if one was even included, and the instruction manual itself calls the antenna virtually worthless.  Buy a cheap powered antenna and get over your disappointment.The little cable for connecting RCA jacks would be handy if there were any software for Linux that could access it.  Sadly this appears to not be the case, and short of configuring WINE, this makes it binnable by the vast majority of you.  I strongly urge you avoid WINE, but hey, it's your computer.  I've put it in the spare parts bin until I find a way to use it.The little extender cable for the USB is handy if you need a little extra length to position your antenna, or, more likely, to get the cable from your box to reach.The remote biscuit «it isn't worthy of the name control» is a nuisance device solely there so you won't whine at the device being $10 too expensive.  I recommend you ship it back to them covered in wet rubber cement.Use the included disc battery to power your travel clock.Obviously, as I don't use Windows, I've binned the CD.The device itself, provided you've followed my suggestion about the antenna or attached it to a cable box, does as advertised.  It's a tuner, both analogue and digital.  That's all.Now, here's what you need:  Kaffeine.  It's in your repository.  It's free.  It works.  You don't even have to restart.That's all.  No special software, no faffing about with .conf files.  Just install it and start it.  You can follow the self-evident procedure from there.  Just remember it's double-click to change channels.  Somehow they never think that might be needed information.Now off you go!  Revel in the fact that Linux is superior in every way.  It just doesn't have a rich daddy to push it on people.

Reviews.Title: it's not just bad software, the hardware is junk too.
Reviews.Author: Steve Kurt
Reviews.Content: In addition to the lousy software described by other reviewers, I'm here to say that the hardware is also junk.  Specifically, the thing runs very hot.  After about 100 hours of use, the heat buildup is sufficient to cause the device to shut down.  Early on, I placed it on a heatsink to get rid of some of the heat, which helped somewhat.  Now, it shuts down after 10 to 30 minutes of use, even with the heatsink.  If I place a blue ice pack on top of it, it'll run for 60 minutes or so.I've been a practicing electrical engineer for nearly 30 years, and if I ever designed something this awful, I'd have to change jobs and become a dishwasher or something that doesn't require skills.  This lousy product is going back to the store!

Reviews.Title: great tuner for your pc.
Reviews.Author: Arthur C Sargent
Reviews.Content: Recently replaced my vista laptop with a windows 8 laptop and needed the ability to record TV programs using Windows Media Center. Reviewed several USB type tuners and decided on this one since it had been described as windows 8 compatible.Installation was easy. Windows 8 automatically loaded the drivers from the internet. Then I only had to go into Media Center and setup the tv settings.Very simple, straight forward, and the picture (HD ones) are fantastic.

Reviews.Title: Does not work correctly with WD Live
Reviews.Author: TAOS Inc
Reviews.Content: I purchased this device to use with my WD Live so I could take advantage of the WD Live's "Watch/record" Live TV feature... and this is the only TV device that works with the Live TV in the USAUnfortunately it doesn't work for several reasons..A) It will only allow you to watch/record Digital channels and not Cable Analog channels (It does state on the website it will allow Clear QAM but doesn't state clearly it's only Digital channels and not Analog too)B) Even with Digital Channels.. it is extremely slow to respond in terms of changing channels..C) Hi Def Digital Channels stutter and jerk during watching and recording rendering them unwatchable.D) Standard Def Digital Channels are likewise, jerky at times (though not as bad as Hi Def ones) but again, most of the time this issue renders them unwatchable.E) The Live TV / Hauppauge software/support in the WD Live is very basic to say the least and crashed on several occasions for no reason.Summary: if you are buying this item to use with your WD Live then don't! I don't know how well it would work with a PC as I use Macs and it is not compatible with Macs using their software though I believe you can use it with other 3rd party software. I didn't test this however as i already have an EyeTV Hybrid which works great with my Macs.. and records both Digital and Analog Clear QAM Cable signals without issue in both Standard and Hi Def modes. Sadly the EyeTv is not compatible with the WD Live...Returned it to Amazon who handled the return quickly and efficiently as always!

Reviews.Title: works like a champ
Reviews.Author: Scott Stillman
Reviews.Content: I have only used it with windows media.  We live on a sailboat and have it hooked up to an antenna on top of the mast. We use it to record broadcast shows.  I haven't had any troubles.

Reviews.Title: It worked
Reviews.Author: Craig T. Bennett II
Reviews.Content: I'm the owner of Tech Reviews and Help, and I bought this to make my Computer into a TV. Simply, it worked. The only bad thing with this is, it does get hot and it is big. But, I used this for 2 years with no other problem.

Reviews.Title: Works great with windows media center.
Reviews.Author: Jacob Nelson
Reviews.Content: This tuner has worked great as a tuner for windows media center, and that is how I recomend using it.For me the Wintv software it came with was buggy crash ridden, and just a pain to use.  Unless you are running an older version of windows (xP or earlier) it isn't worth installing.I also tried to do a linux based mythtv setup using this tuner, but for me it proved to be too much of a hassle (and I know linux).  I read that there are many people who have had good luck with it, but unless your familiar with the quirks of mythtv and video capture in linux it'll probably take an entire afternoon or more to get it working correctly.With windows media center on win 7 all I had to do is plug it in and let it search out the channels, and I was rewarded with a functional dvr that gave me full 5.1 surround sound with minimal config, in about 1.5 hours.I haven't tried the remote or the AV input. But so far I am loving this tuner.

Reviews.Title: Coolest Technology Purchase This Year!
Reviews.Author: Jonathan Parker
Reviews.Content: I have gotten out of the habit of writing reviews and doing surveys for companies, but this product made me break my rule...  because it's awesome!  It tunes better than any flat screen TV I have in my house and has a great DVR.  There was a little hitch when I installed it:  You must install the drivers and then reboot before installing the software and USB unit.  Also, I tried to install it on my Ultrabook, but could not since it only has one USB port.  The USB hub I have is old, so I put it on my desktop computer...  Which turned out to be the right thing since you can't keep moving arount your receiver and antenna, especially if you use the DVR.  I will suggest that you purchase the "Paper Thin Leaf Indoor HDTV Antenna - Made in the USA! by Mohu" from Amazon.  WOrks better than the supplied antenna.Paper Thin Leaf Indoor HDTV Antenna - Made in the USA!

Reviews.Title: consumer
Reviews.Author: triplett4
Reviews.Content: Mostly works okay except for the remote control.  I use the remote that is for MS Media Center.  It works much better.

Reviews.Title: Outstanding!!!
Reviews.Author: Eddie
Reviews.Content: I mainly wanted this to pick up local broadcast channels in my Laptop. Initially, the tuner didn't work using the drivers in the CD. I then downloaded updated drivers from Hauppauge's website and it worked flawlessly. To make the Remote Control work, just go to the IR32 folder in the CD-ROM and run the IR32 file. Now the Remote also works excellente with Windows 7 Media Center even from 10 feet away!Recommended!

Reviews.Title: Works as advertised, but watch for video card driver problems
Reviews.Author: M. Maynard
Reviews.Content: I use this with Windows 7 Media Center (32-bit.) I had no problems installing it - Windows automatically downloaded and installed drivers, then Media Center was able to find the tuner and scan for our local channels.However, after that smooth experience I went to watch live TV, and there was only a blank screen, although the sound came through OK. I then found I could not view recorded TV from my other WMC7 box or DVDs either, though I had been able to do both before installing the tuner.I finally called Hauppage Tech Support and was talking to a support person within a few minutes. He quickly suggested to get less recent NVidia drivers. I went to the NVidia website and downloaded a driver version right before the most recent one, and then everything worked.The Hauppage guy implied that the problem was NVidia broke something, and I can certainly understand his perspective. However, HD video playback in WMC7 did work fine _before_ I installed the Hauppage tuner, so I am betting that they are the ones who ultimately will have to come up with the fix. He said that the included WinTV video playback software would have worked with the newest drivers.The tuner seems to pull in channels at least as well as the tuner in my new 42" LG TV. I get all of the 20 or so channels in my extended local area with no problems. Stations in neighboring Cincinnati about 45 miles away do not come in, at least not via the cheap rabbit ears I have sitting on the table behind the TV set.

Reviews.Title: Hauppauge WinTV-HVR-950Q TV Tuner
Reviews.Author: Mick
Reviews.Content: I purchased this Hauppauge WinTV-HVR-950Q TV Tuner a month or so ago...I am using a  laptop with Win 7 32 bit enterprise edition ( I was thinking of installing 64 bit WIN 7 one day ), 4 GIG Ram,  Intel HD Graphics video, for the Screen I am using an externally attached Samsung SyncMater 2243 , 8000:1 Dynamic Contrast.This Laptop is only used for television and this USB TV Tuner.So far this USB TV tuner is working well.The USB stick tends to get Hot after long term use.Wintv Software is not the best but useable.I have used this software to record old VCR Tapes to PC to convert to DVD.The Hauppauge WinTV-HVR-950Q TV Tuner comes with RCA connections which I also use with my satellite receiver.I have been using the WINtv software with the satellite as well.I have used the Windows Media to view the satellite TV, it does not work so well, it will not detect the RCA Connection Composite connection, I have read you need a special Win Media Remote for this option, which I do not feel I need to purchase. I am using this with a satellite; I change the channels with the satellite remote. Win Media will not detect the RCA Composite input; The Satellite Receiver has no Coaxial Output, only RCA, HDMI.I used an RF Modulator for the Out to the USB Coaxial Input, Win 7 Media Player did not detect the necessary Channel, and I had to manually add Channel 3 or 4.The Wintv software seems to be a better solution to this, it has not crashed yet, and the clarity is good.Using the USb Hauppauge WinTV-HVR-950Q TV Tuner as over the air reception, Win 7 Media works best for this.The Supplied remote works well. It takes some time for Win 7 Media to configure and find channels, once set up, works best. You can record Television as well.I use the Wintv software for the satellite, if my electricity goes out, I open the Win 7 media player, switch to over the air reception.I did try the QAM in Florida using Comcast, it detected a number of channels, but was unable to use as the channels were locked.I had no problems installing the drivers or the software needed on my Win 7 PC.For those whom might have a problem, uninstall the device from the system device manger, uninstall all software, then restart PC, then reinstall only the drivers, then the software.  (I installed on a different PC, this is what I had to do to correctly install)This can not replace a Real TV, there seems to be a Delay, I have not tried using this with a video game, when I select TV Guide on the Satellite, there is a 3 to 5 second delay. Using with Media Player there is an even greater delay, and sometimes the audio becomes out of sync. Restarting the PC usually fixes this. I am uncertain if this is the PC, Software or the Satellite.In the end, it is a fairly cool thing to have and use, especially if you're traveling, or your electricity goes out often.Update:::::::: 2/11/2012I have Changed my operating system in the dedicated laptop I am using to WIN 7 Ultimate 64 Bit, 4GB Ram, Intel HD Graphics video, for the Screen I am using an externally attached Samsung SyncMater 2243.I have connected the Wii via RCA / Composite Cable, open wintv7 go to Advanced Options then I  selected - Game Mode for analog ( Slip Disabled )there is no lag I can play video games .  The only down side is, the Slip is disabled which means while watching Live tv I can not rewind or pause.The USB Tuner itself gets very warm, the composite plug in seems loose I have to move it a little for the sound to work correctly.The wintv7 software if you select the update option will take you to the Wintv7 web page to Update the software after you pay for the update. I have not and will not be doing that.I have been using the wintv7 software for watching Satellite TV and playing the Wii, to change the Channel in the WInTv takes forever sometimes. If I watch over the air TV ( Rare that I do ) I use either Windows Media Center or Media Portal . Media Portal Software ( [...] ) is free and very interesting, a bit of a hassle to set up but does allot of interesting things such as You can watch what your TV Tuner card is tuned to on a different PC, if the main PC with tuner card has more than one tuner card a remote PC can change the channels, as if the tuner card was installed, and this is Free. The problem is it is a bit of a pain to set up. I am considering purchasing an additional TV Tuner Card for this purpose.One last observation.using the WintTV7 software. There is a folder named Pause Buffer, this folder holds the files livetv files, and this fills up fast, It seems if you restart the Wintv7 program it deletes these files, I have reach the Maximum space on my PC in this folder, I had to physically go in and delete these files. My hard drive is 148GB and this PC is used solely for this TV card. If you open the pause buffer folder, you can see these files being added as you watch TV.Update, attempted to use this with Linux and MythTV, really a hassle to get the drivers installed and this device to reconize. spend an extra few dollars and get the networked SiliconDust HDHomeRun DUAL High Definition Digital TV Tuner. Thou I havent gotten this to work with windows Media Center yet..

Reviews.Title: First time with a TV Turner
Reviews.Author: scifijunkie
Reviews.Content: Well I would have to say that the Turner does work. It seems to get warm after awhile, I don't know if is because it is drawing that much power or if it is trying that hard to get the over the air TV channels and where I live at there is really just satellite by the means of any TV at all so I have to wait until I got into a area that I could pick up any TV channels. When I did I was able to get good signal with the antenna that it came with but it was not perfect. Other then that it does work even on a netbook running Windows 7 Starter.

Reviews.Title: works as advertised
Reviews.Author: Colino
Reviews.Content: Does exactly what its supposed to with my clearQAM signal from Cox Communications. I use it with Windows media center in windows 7, for which it works seamlessly. The software that comes with it is OK, but not as good as the windows one. Not sure if it works with xp media player as well, but the bundled software would work OK in that case. I use the cable signal, but also tried the enclosed antenna. It received about 1/2 the channels it was supposed to, and depended strongly on orientation, so you may need an external antenna if you don't plan to use the clearQAM signal. Also, you may need a USB extender as the one that comes with it is pretty short, but they are pretty cheap. For the less than average software, OK antenna and short USB, I only gave it 4 stars, but for windows media center used as the software and clearQAM signals, it is worth the full 5.

Reviews.Title: Great "traveler's" TV tuner
Reviews.Author: Cary L. Brown
Reviews.Content: This review is for the most recent revision of the 950Q, purchased in January of 2012.  It's worth pointing out that this is a different package than that sold previously, with the same model number.  The back of my stick reads as follows:NTSC/ATSC/QAM HD TV receiver72001 LF Rev B4F0  4311.(It also lists a unique MAC address, which you may need if dealing with your local cable company)The box this shipped in is a smaller box than shown in the images, above, and instead of the white styrofoam insert, there's a brown corrugated cardboard insert.The stick is present, as is the little AV patch cable, and the antenna, as well as a remote.  I say "A remote" because the remote provided is NOT the remote shown in the images above.  My remote is not the type with a membrane switch face, and would not slip into the card slot of a laptop (and since those slots are not even included anymore, that makes sense).  The new remote has the same raised rubber buttons most remotes have, albeit in a small and portable form factor.  It seems as though there are a couple of buttons on the other remote which aren't present on this one, but since I can't see a close-up of the other remote, I can't be certain.The remote I was provided with seems to work fine, but there's a significant "lag" between using it and having the WinTV 7 software respond.  (By the way, this package came with the latest version of WinTV7, v2.4d, on CD, which leads me to conclude that this is a newer release, not an older one, though there's no way to be certain).The antenna seems to work better than I'd have expected, and should be more than servicable for my "travel use" needs.  I need to get a slim coax cable to travel with to patch into cable TV as well, and that's not provided here... only the antenna is provided.  But the antenna works nicely... I was able to get 16 channels here in Austin, TX, while the FCC's site suggested I could only expect to receive about ten.It's worth noting that I get more channels using the provided WinTV  application than I do when using Windows Media Center.  I fail to see why the provided application would receive more, but it does.  I get about ten channels using WMC, with the rest being "below threshold."The antenna provided is acceptable, but a better antenna will undoubtedly improve overall reception.  I plan to obtain a "leaf plus" antenna (which should be easy to carry when traveling) which will, if reports hold true, double the number of receivable stations for me.  We'll see.  Of course, a real, outdoors directional antenna would be a huge benefit, but that's impractical for a device whose main reason for existence is to be PORTABLE, after all.As several others have mentioned, the device becomes warm.  Not "HOT" (ie, you can still touch it) but it clearly draws a lot of power.  Your best bet, long-term, is to use it with an external, powered USB hub.  However, it works just fine off my little netbook's internal power.  The install guide recommends not using it with a hub, but that seems clearly to be more about power than about "lag," and going through an externally-powered hub should cause no problems.  (I plan to obtain a new 8-port powered hub later tonight, and I'll revise this review if this changes.)The remote isn't "ideal" but is acceptable.  However, I strongly recommend trying a little device made by a Chinese company called "Riitek."  You'll find several variations of that being sold on Amazon right now, and often using different names (usually the exporter selling it into the USA, not the original manufacturer, though).I have this little device in both BT and 2.4Ghz radio versions.  Unless you find the idea of using a "dongle" undesirable, I actually prefer the 2.4Ghz version overall, though they're effectively identical in most ways.  Here's the one I bought... though the name it's listed under on Amazon has changed since I bought it.http://www.amazon.com/FAVI-Entertainment-Wireless-Keyboard-TouchPad/dp/B003UE52ME/ref=cm_cr_pr_pb_tAnd here's the Blutooth version...  which is nicer, overall, but nearly identical... and which has the minor drawback of occasionally dropping connection in "blutooth-heavy" environments (like, say, airports).http://www.amazon.com/Wireless-Bluetooth-Keyboard-Cellphones-touchpad/dp/B0042VF30U/ref=sr_1_3?s=electronics&ie;=UTF8&qid;=1326141350&sr;=1-3You'll find these sold by a number of folks on Amazon.  ALL are made by Riitek.  They're GREAT devices, frankly, and are of high-quality (unlike so many Chinese-made-and-designed objects I've dealt with over the years).  I'm very happy with them, and strongly recommend them.  Using this as a "remote mini-keyboard and mouse" easily replaces your little Hauppauge remote, especially when working with Windows Media Center.

Reviews.Title: One and Done
Reviews.Author: S. Manus
